PKG101.name: Principles of Packaging
PKG101.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PKG101.description: Packaging systems, materials and forms and their relationship to the needs and wants of society.

PKG102.name: Introductory Packaging Seminar
PKG102.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PKG102.description: Packaging career choices in science, management and engineering. Creativity in packaging designs and career decisions.
PKG102.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Packaging Major.

PKG221.name: Packaging with Glass and Metal
PKG221.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PKG221.description: Physical and chemical properties of glass and metals and their applications to packaging.
PKG221.prerequisite: (CEM 141 or CEM 151 or LB 171) and (PHY 231 or PHY 231C or PHY 183 or PHY 183B or LB 273) and (PKG 102 or concurrently)
PKG221.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the Packaging Major.

PKG315.name: Packaging Decision Systems
PKG315.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PKG315.description: Communication, analysis, and problem solving in the management, specification, production, sustainability, economics and testing of packaging.
PKG315.prerequisite: (MTH 132 or MTH 152H or LB 118) and (PKG 221 or concurrently)
PKG315.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the School of Packaging.

PKG322.name: Packaging with Paper and Paperboard
PKG322.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PKG322.description: Physical and chemical properties, manufacture, conversion, and use of wood, paper, paperboard, and related components in packaging. Design, use, and evaluation of packages.
PKG322.prerequisite: ((PKG 221 or concurrently) and PKG 101) and (MTH 133 or MTH 153H or LB 119) and (CEM 143 or CEM 251 or CEM 351) and (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 315 or STT 351)
PKG322.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors or graduate students in the School of Packaging.

PKG323.name: Packaging with Plastics
PKG323.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PKG323.description: Physical and chemical properties of plastics and their relationship to selection, design, manufacture, performance, and evaluation of packages.
PKG323.prerequisite: ((PKG 221 or concurrently) and PKG 101) and (MTH 133 or MTH 153H or LB 119) and (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 315 or STT 351) and (CEM 143 or CEM 251 or CEM 351)
PKG323.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors or graduate students in the School of Packaging.

PKG410.name: Distribution Packaging Dynamics
PKG410.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PKG410.description: Identification and measurement of hazards in physical distribution. Methods of protection against climate, shock, vibration, and compression.
PKG410.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors or graduate students in the School of Packaging.

PKG411.name: Package Development Technology
PKG411.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PKG411.description: Development of consumer packaging utilizing current technology tools. Integration of package structure, graphics and performance. Examination and application of current practices in packaging development.
PKG411.prerequisite: (PKG 322 and PKG 323) and ((PKG 315 or concurrently) or EGR 102)

PKG421.name: Virtual Design and Prototyping
PKG421.description: Using technology resources to design and integrate packaging structure and graphics. Use of design thinking for package development. Virtual and physical prototyping. Emphasis on packaging for specialized markets.

PKG430.name: Packaging for Fast-Moving Consumer Goods
PKG430.description: Package graphics and structure in fast-moving consumer goods packaging and marketing. Consumer experience, printing and decoration. Preparation, production, and economics of packaging graphics.
PKG430.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the School of Packaging.

PKG432.name: Packaging Processes
PKG432.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PKG432.description: Integrated study of packaging and production operations, quality control, and organization and control of machines. Interrelationship of products, packaging, machinery layout and efficiency, and quality issues.
PKG432.prerequisite: (PKG 322 and PKG 323) and (PHY 232 or PHY 232C or PHY 184 or PHY 184B or PHY 294H or LB 274)
PKG432.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors or graduate students in the School of Packaging.

PKG444.name: Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) for Packaging
PKG444.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PKG444.description: Automatic identification tags, codes, and hardware and software for radio frequency identification (RFID). Business applications. Effect of products, materials, packaging, warehousing, supply chain, and quality on radio frequency equipment and readability.
PKG444.prerequisite: PKG 322 and PKG 323 or approval of school

PKG445.name: Robotics in Packaging
PKG445.description: Robotic systems. Configurations, components, drive mechanisms, control and feedback, and safety. Line inspection, vision systems, guided vehicle, and storage retrieval systems.
PKG445.prerequisite: MTH 124 or MTH 132 or LB 118 or MTH 152H

PKG450.name: Automotive and Industrial Packaging
PKG450.description: Returnable and expendable packaging for part shipments to assembly plants, cost justification, service parts packaging, logistical systems, and material handling.
PKG450.prerequisite: MTH 124 or MTH 132 or LB 118 or MTH 152H

PKG452.name: Medical Packaging
PKG452.description: Special requirements for packaging pharmaceuticals and medical devices. Evaluation of package systems and packaging procedures.

PKG455.name: Food Packaging
PKG455.description: Food package systems and their relationship to specific products and processes. Product composition, deterioration and packaging-solutions. Shelf life, packaging, and supply chain issues
PKG455.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors or graduate students in the School of Packaging or approval of department.

PKG456.name: Packaging and Shelf Life of Perishable Food
PKG456.description: Chemical, physical and microbiological changes that affect quality of produce, meat, and seafood, and their relationship to packaging and distribution (cold chain). Packaging and preservation technologies to extend shelf life of perishable food.
PKG456.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors or graduate students in the School of Packaging or approval of department.

PKG465.name: Packaging Value Chain
PKG465.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
PKG465.description: Integrated identification and measurement of packaging supply chain components, from material extraction through processing, shipping, warehousing, sales and disposal. Integration of information technologies. Application and interrelationship of costs and financial aspects to the decision-making processes.
PKG465.restrictions: Open to students in the School of Packaging.

PKG470.name: Packaging Sustainability
PKG470.description: Effects of packaging on sustainability and environmental quality. Solid waste and recycling. Air and water quality. Laws, economics and energy. Resource use and conservation. Life cycle analysis.
PKG470.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the School of Packaging.

PKG477.name: Hazardous Materials Packaging
PKG477.description: Packaging hazardous materials. Title 49 of the U.S. Code of Federal Regulations. Product classes, use of regulations, exceptions, authorized packaging, and the performance testing program.
PKG477.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

PKG480.name: Packaging Laws and Regulations
PKG480.description: History and development of packaging laws and regulations. Relationships among law, government regulation and commercial regulation. Effect of current laws and regulations on packaging.
PKG480.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors or graduate students in the School of Packaging.

PKG485.name: Packaging Development (W)
PKG485.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PKG485.description: Package development including selection, design and implementation of package systems for protection, distribution, merchandising, use and disposal.
PKG485.prerequisite: ((PKG 410 and PKG 432) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) and (PKG 315 or EGR 102) and (PKG 411 or concurrently)
PKG485.restrictions: Open to seniors or graduate students in the School of Packaging.

PKG490.name: Directed Studies in Packaging Problems
PKG490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PKG490.description: Development of solutions to specific packaging problems. Supervised individual study.
PKG490.restrictions: Open to sophomores or seniors or graduate students. Approval of department; application required.

PKG491.name: Special Topics
PKG491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

PKG492.name: Senior Seminar
PKG492.description: Seminar on current packaging issues, business organization and operations, and accepted practices in a corporate environment.
PKG492.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Packaging major.

PKG493.name: Professional Internship in Packaging
PKG493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PKG493.description: Supervised professional experience in the field of packaging offered through corporations and other businesses throughout the U.S.
PKG493.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the School of Packaging. Approval of department; application required. A student may earn a maximum of 6 credits in all enrollments for any or all of these courses

PKG499.name: Undergraduate Research
PKG499.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PKG499.description: Undergraduate research project designed to enhance critical thinking, problem-solving, teamwork, and communication skills.
PKG499.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Packaging Major. Approval of school.

PKG801.name: Packaging Materials
PKG801.description: Physical and chemical properties of packaging materials; design, manufacture, performance and evaluation of packages.

PKG803.name: Packaging Distribution and Dynamics
PKG803.description: Transportation environment, distribution packaging design and testing.

PKG804.name: Packaging Processes
PKG804.description: Integrated study of packaging and production operations, quality control, organization and control of machines. Interrelationship of products, packaging, machinery layout and efficiency, and quality issues.

PKG805.name: Advanced Packaging Dynamics
PKG805.description: Shock and vibration. Distribution hazards and product fragility. Cushion performance and package design. Environmental measurement and simulation.

PKG814.name: Packaging for Food Safety
PKG814.description: Current issues in packaging and food safety.
PKG814.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Food Safety major and open to graduate students in the Packaging major or approval of college.

PKG815.name: Permeability and Shelf Life
PKG815.description: Relationship between the storage life of packaged food and pharmaceutical products and the gas, moisture, and organic vapor permeability of packages in various environments.

PKG817.name: Instruments for Analysis of Packaging Materials
PKG817.description: Analytical methods for packaging including spectrophotometry and chromatography. Material identification and characterization. Migration and permeation measurements.

PKG825.name: Polymeric Packaging Materials
PKG825.description: Physical, mechanical and chemical properties of packaging polymers and multilayer structures; relationship between properties and performance of packaging materials and systems; processing of packaging plastics.

PKG840.name: Anti-Counterfeit Strategy and Product Protection
PKG840.description: Theory and applied techniques for anti-counterfeit strategies and product protection for food and consumer products.
PKG840.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Criminal Justice or in the School of Packaging or in the Food Safety major or approval of department.

PKG850.name: Packaging Value Chain
PKG850.description: Packaging value chain from raw material supplier to retailers in context of meeting current needs. Global exploration of value chain strategies to increase innovation, sustainability, cost savings, quality, organizational agility, responsiveness.

PKG860.name: Research Methods
PKG860.description: Principles and expectations for responsible conduct of research in packaging. Integrity of the research process, critical thinking, scientific methods, proposal writing, and scientific communications.

PKG875.name: Stability and Recyclability of Packaging Materials
PKG875.description: Interactions between packaging materials and environments

PKG880.name: Life Cycle Assessment: Background, Principles, Calculations, and Applications
PKG880.description: Determination of the environmental footprint of products, packages and systems during their entire life-cycle using life cycle assessment (LCA) methodology. Introduction to the theory and application of LCA.

PKG888.name: Master's Project
PKG888.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PKG888.description: Master's degree Plan B project. Completion of a project related to packaging issues.
PKG888.restrictions: Open only to master's students in the School of Packaging. Approval of school, application required.

PKG890.name: Independent Study in Packaging
PKG890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PKG890.description: Special investigations of unique packaging problems.
PKG890.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the School of Packaging. Approval of department; application required.

PKG891.name: Selected Topics
PKG891.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PKG891.description: Selected topics of interest to graduate packaging students.
PKG891.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the School of Packaging.

PKG899.name: Master's Thesis Research
PKG899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PKG899.restrictions: Open only to master's students in the Packaging major.

PKG985.name: Analytical Solutions to Packaging Design
PKG985.description: Analytical and quantitative techniques for packaging design and evaluation.
PKG985.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or College of Engineering or College of Natural Science. Approval of department; application required.

PKG990.name: Independent Study in Packaging
PKG990.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PKG990.description: Special investigations of unique packaging problems.
PKG990.restrictions: Open only to Ph.D. students in the School of Packaging. Approval of department; application required.

PKG992.name: Packaging Seminar
PKG992.description: Presentations of detailed studies on specialized aspects of packaging.
PKG992.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the School of Packaging.

PKG999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
PKG999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PKG999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the School of Packaging.
